body: @CalvinLloyd117 I would train with the new version, as that has changed significantly since rc3, and not everything from RC's are backwards compatible (as noted in release notes). For this, I would make a new project, then you can copy in the labeled-data folder (but not the cropped folders), and edit config; there is no original video list anymore, etc. The networks, etc have also changed since RC3, so you are very, very likely to have better performance, hope that helps!
Thanks! I will do that, and get back to you here.

Hi 

I am working on pose estimation on Marmosets using ma-DLC. I have an issue where plotted points on refining tracklets are way too different compare to the create video for checking detection. Major plotted points' swap between male and female marmosets were occurred along the refining tracklets. Some even mixed wrongly for the body parts. How can I fixed them without refining them one by one throughout the frames? This is my config.yaml and inference_config.yaml. Please help.
.
.
.
# Project definitions (do not edit)
Task: '00022'
scorer: advm
date: Jan22
multianimalproject: true
identity: false

    # Project path (change when moving around)
project_path: C:\Users\adam\00022-adam-2022-01-22

    # Annotation data set configuration (and individual video cropping parameters)
video_sets:
  C:\Users\adam\00022-adam-2022-01-22\videos\00022.mp4:
    crop: 0, 1340, 0, 1080
individuals:
- male
- female
uniquebodyparts: []
multianimalbodyparts:
- rightear
- forehead
- leftear
- chin
- chest
- tail1
- tail2
- tail3
- tail4
- tail5
skeleton:
- - rightear
  - forehead
- - forehead
  - leftear
- - forehead
  - chin
- - chin
  - chest
- - chest
  - tail1
- - tail1
  - tail2
- - tail2
  - tail3
- - tail3
  - tail4
- - tail4
  - tail5
bodyparts: MULTI!
start: 0
stop: 1
numframes2pick: 20

    # Plotting configuration
skeleton_color: yellow
pcutoff: 0.6
dotsize: 12
alphavalue: 0.7
colormap: rainbow

    # Training,Evaluation and Analysis configuration
TrainingFraction:
- 0.95
iteration: 0
default_net_type: resnet_50
default_augmenter: multi-animal-imgaug
snapshotindex: -1
batch_size: 4

    # Cropping Parameters (for analysis and outlier frame detection)
cropping: false
    #if cropping is true for analysis, then set the values here:
x1: 0
x2: 640
y1: 277
y2: 624

    # Refinement configuration (parameters from annotation dataset configuration also relevant in this stage)
corner2move2:
- 50
- 50
move2corner: true
.
.
.
.
.
.
boundingboxslack: 0
iou_threshold: 0.6
max_age: 1
method: m1
min_hits: 1
minimalnumberofconnections: 5
pafthreshold: 0.1
pcutoff: 0.1
topktoretain: 2
variant: 0
withid: false
@advmsbrdn16, please open a separate issue; this will make troubleshooting easier.

Hello again,

I just wanted to let you know that retraining on the new version was generally good advice. I made a fresh project and copied in labeled data as instructed, and modified the new config. It also involved going through all labeled videos and essentially resaving, since the structure of the data has changed between the DLC version and the files could not be concatenated since they were incompatible when creating the training data set. Tracking does appear to be better now. 

However, the original issue I submitted about persists. Modifying the inference_cfg.yaml file for the current iteration (now 0 in the new project) has no impact on the tracklets. 

Edit: It seems that the only value within the inference_cfg.yaml that is being utilized/is required is _topktoretain_. Not sure if this will help with troubleshooting or not, but I thought I would share.

Glad to hear tracking is improved! So to clarify, two things:

(1) which parameters are you changing and the range? https://deeplabcut.github.io/DeepLabCut/docs/maDLC_UserGuide.html#decision-break-point
```
# Tracking:
#p/m pixels in width and height for increasing bounding boxes.
boundingboxslack : 0
# Intersection over Union (IoU) threshold for linking two bounding boxes
iou_threshold: .2
# maximum duration of a lost tracklet before it's considered a "new animal" (in frames)
max_age: 100
# minimum number of consecutive frames before a detection is tracked
min_hits: 3
```
(2) what are you trying to improve, i.e., what is the issue in the tracking we can help with :)

I am changing max_age, iou_threshold (0-1), and especially min_hits. The main issue is that tracklets are being misplaced (labeling the grass or a tree instead of the animal) for a single frame and then disappearing. I would usually fix this with min_hits (maybe 3). However, changing the value of min_hits does nothing at all. Even making min_hits impossible (eg. 100 which is longer than the video) does not change tracking.

Again, nothing in the file makes a difference to the tracking performance, except topktoretain.

What tracking method are you using @CalvinLloyd117? `ellipse`, the default one?
So you edit the config manually then rerun `convert_detections2tracklets` via the GUI, right?

I have tried ellipse and box, which both work well for me. I typically just leave it as the default for general use.

Yes, I have tried all of the following:

A)
1) Modify the inference_cfg.yaml and save the file.
2) Use the GUI to analyze video.
3) Go to OPT: Refine Tracklets in the GUI, setting Number of animals (in this case 1) and selecting the video.
4) Click Refine tracks GUI Launch
5) View the tracklets in the new window.
6) Delete/move all generated files from analysis
7) Modify inference_cfg.yaml and save
8) complete steps 2-5 again
Results are the same.

B)
Performing the same general steps, using ipython rather than GUI
1) Modify the inference_cfg.yaml and save the file.
2) Run `deeplabcut.analyze_videos(. . .)`
3) Run `deeplabcut.refine_tracklets(. . .)` and view the produced tracklets
4) Delete/move all generated files from analysis
5) Modify inference_cfg.yaml and save
6) complete steps 2-5 again.
Results are the same ( and the same as method A)

C)
Performing essentially B, except with `auto_track=False` in `deeplabcut.analyze_videos(. . .)`
1) Modify the inference_cfg.yaml and save the file.
2) Run `deeplabcut.analyze_videos(. . .)` setting `auto_track=False`
3) Run `deeplabcut.convert_detections2tracklets(. . .)`
4) Run `deeplabcut.stitch_tracklets(. . .)`
5) Run `deeplabcut.refine_tracklets(. . .)`
6) View generated trackets in the new window
7) Delete/move files created through analysis and tracklet creation
8) Modify inference_cfg.yaml and save
9) perform steps 2-6 again
Results are the same (And the same as methods A and B)

I have also tried variations of the above including with `overwrite=True` in `deeplabcut.convert_detections2tracklets(. . .)` (but this value cannot be found in the docs anymore, so maybe it has been retired.)

In general, results are always the same within the same method, and between methods. No matter what values I set in inference_cfg.yaml, tracklets are always identical.
Great, thank you for the detailed description! I'll dig into it and get back to you when I have an explanation ðŸ˜„

@CalvinLloyd117, here is a couple of observations after looking at tracking in details on 2 of our datasets. In short, all 3 relevant tracking parameters work as I would expect.

- `iou_overlap`: the higher it is, the larger the number of false negatives, MOTA drops, and tracking becomes very slow (e.g., with iou_overlap=1, there is no matching at all between a tracker and an animal, so trackers are being created/deleted in every frame, MOTA=0)
- `max_age` (i.e., the maximal durationâ€”in # of framesâ€”a tracker can stay outdated before being deleted): if set to 0, tracking requires many more trackers overall and creates more fragments (tracking interruptions) than if set to 10 for example
- `min_hits`: the higher it is, the higher the number of false negatives (similar to iou_overlap) with a very marked decrease in tracking accuracy (expectedly, as this is equivalent to filtering sporadic detections in favor of longer, high-quality tracklets). There is an exception though if `min_hits` is set to a number larger than the number of frames: this has no effect because of 
the following line:
https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/9ae1d47f437008fea42a41a7d97fb274398fd270/deeplabcut/pose_estimation_tensorflow/lib/trackingutils.py#L506
where `self.n_frames <= self.min_hits` then always evaluates to True.

Reflecting back on what you describe though, and in particular "labeling the grass or a tree instead of the animal", prompts me to ask: have you tried to run `deeplabcut.create_video_with_all_detections`? If tracklets are "misplaced", this has likely more to do with spurious (grouping of) detections than tracking, which only sees already assembled individuals. Another simple diagnosis tool is to reevaluate your network passing `deeplabcut.evaluate_network(..., plotting='individual'): this will create labeled images with detections colored by individuals, allowing you to judge how good your model is at reconstructing poses. I hope that helps! ðŸ˜Š

Thanks so much for looking into this for me. I really appreciate it!

After a re-read of the documentation, I came across a little note within the animal assembly and tracking section:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45299786/152564213-306c8a11-1d1f-4283-8127-3c4db71f5369.png)

I believe this is explaining why the inference_cfg.yaml has no impact in my situation. For my use case, I have a variety of videos, some multi animal, and some single animal. The number of monkeys varies quite a bit. For the project I am working on now, I am only tracking one animal, using a multi-animal project. The way tracking a single animal works now treats the project as a single animal project, which does not use the inference_cfg. This is definitely a new way to do it since I updated DLC last, since before, single animals were tracked using multi-animal methods.

A quick follow up question: Are there any adjustable parameters besides p-cutoff (in config.yaml) that can be modified to influence single animal tracking within a multi-animal project? I have also been tinkering a bit with filtering methods, but only median filtering seems to work well for me in this case.

indeed single animals should not be tracked in the same way, i.e., so this is changed (but since rc versions, which we note were subject to API changes :). If you have outliers, I would rather focus on refining the model, otherwise, only the assembly affects performance; you can check out the preprint with covers the data calibration mode, hope that helps, and glad the behavior is resolved in the since as it's working as intended :D! 

filtering is always a good choice, but otherwise pcutoff and data_calibration for assembly, and carefully check input data, check many snpashots, be sure your model is trained enough.
